As a native of Long Island NY, Chef Doug Psaltis began his career working in his grandfather’s diner at the age of 10. From there, he’s worked in some of the most acclaimed restaurants in the world under chef Alain Ducasse, including New York’s Mix, where Doug was the chef de cuisine. He is the first American chef ever to be given that title in a Ducasse restaurant.

In Chicago, Chef Psaltis is mostly known for his Italian cuisine and highly successful restaurant, RPM, a destination in Chicago for locals and tourists. He is one of the busiest chefs in the city, spending much of his time working on concepts for his many restaurants under the Lettuce Entertain You brand.

doug's restaurants

RPM Italian
Check Doug's mediterranean grilled chicken baba
ghanoush, zaatar & harissa recipe

Scoring

When you score meatier vegetables, it allows for caramelization on the outside, bringing out more flavor.

Chicken pinching

When determining if a whole chicken is fully cooked on the grill, just pinch between the two bones on the wing. If your fingers can meet, then it’s done. This is an old trick that works for any size bird and hasn’t proven Chef Psaltis wrong yet.

Za’atar

It’s a Mediterranean mixture of dried oregano, sesame seed and sumac. It’s also one of Chef Psaltis’s favorite little secrets on chicken, fish and even salad. He always has this spice on hand when cooking at home.

Q & A

Which Mariano’s do you shop?

Mariano’s West Loop.

Who does the shopping?

Myself and my wife.

What’s it like creating menus for so many types of cuisine?

Very exciting and inspiring...I am always learning and teaching, which is my true passion.

What sparks your creativity?

Travel.

What’s a typical meal you cook at home on Sundays?

Roasted chicken, homemade dim sum or BBQ when the weather is right.

If there was one tip you could give when it comes to experimentation, what would it be?

Study and understand the basics and foundations of the cuisine you are looking to experiment with first.

Is there a style of cooking you have been meaning to attempt?

Moroccan cuisine. I was part of a Moroccan concept in NYC and was intrigued and inspired by their rich culinary history. I’ve always been interested in learning more about their spices and cooking methods.

What’s your favorite style to cook?

Mediterranean.

What do you do when you’re not feeling very creative?

Read and travel.

Any guilty pleasures?

Tons. Great cheese, Nutella, chicken wings and pepperoni pizza.
